Award.AwardTitle: Mechanochemical Sensation of Damage in the Pericellular Niche

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this award is to understand the mechanisms by which cells target the damaged regions of bone for repair. The skeleton sustains microscopic damage as part of daily activities and cells curb microcrack accumulation by a continual repair process. Recent studies demonstrated that calcium is released from damaged regions of bone and such a release may initiate bone-repair cascade. This project will build on this insight and will characterize the response of bone cells to calcium release from bone. In combination, the studies will draw a more complete picture which unifies calcium release from the matrix, identify the route via which calcium enters the cells and the types of molecules which are activated upon calcium transport.

Successful attainment of the aims of this award will improve our understanding of the mechanisms which drive skeletal repair. Insight on skeletal repair creates the potential to mitigate various conditions of skeletal fragility, including osteoporosis. Another merit of award-related activities is the creation of the foundation for designing intelligent biomaterials which can repair themselves by regulating cell response. If observed calcium release from damaged substrate triggers matrix-repair by cells, the proposed activities would cultivate efforts to design bone like materials which induce resident cells to repair critically loaded regions. Female participation in engineering careers has been increasing; however, this engagement needs to be sustained into the future. On the outreach front, high-school female students will participate in research activities to foster their interests in pursuing careers in engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Bone tissue suffers continual microdamage that undergoes remodeling to sustain its structural integrity. Daily physiological activity may induce two types of microdamage on bone matrix: linear microcrack and diffuse microdamage. Linear microcracks induce osteocyte apoptosis which are then repaired by basic multicellular unit. On the other hand, how bone cells detect and respond to diffuse microdamage is not understood clearly.

This study demonstrated bone matrix as a mechanotransducer which converts mechanical signal into chemical changes in the pericellular niche to activate anabolic function of osteoblasts. Under post-yield tensile loading, diffuse microdamage induced calcium efflux (D-MICE) from bone matrix activates intracellular calcium signaling in osteoblasts and osteoprogenitor cells. L-type and T-type voltage gated calcium channels were identified to be involved in the activation. Also, D-MICE activated key transcription factors for osteoblastic function which was then followed by synthesis of mineralized matrix. Therefore, the major finding of this project is a novel mechanism of bone repair induced by diffuse microdamage, by providing a complete diagram of calcium entry, associated transcription pathways and the nature of the transduced response of osteoblasts. Another finding was that osteocytes did not seem to be activated by D-MICE.

Another key finding on this project is osteoinductive effect of short span calcium stimulus. Current clinically available methods, such as calcium sulfate bone defect filler, may induce adverse effects, such as transient hypercalcemia and inflammatory responses by rapid resorption. Repetitive calcium stimulus showed osteoinductive effect on preosteoblasts to an extent comparable and at times better than that attained by BMP-2. Therefore repetitive administration of supraphysiological level of calcium was suggested to improve bone healing while minimizing such adverse effects from current therapeutic methods. The knowledge gained on these modes of calcium application will be critically important for developing calcium delivery modalities.

This project provided training and educational opportunities to students in Case Western Reserve University and enhanced the participation of high school students in the community. The project supported one PhD student, four journal articles and two conference proceedings. Also, this project provided training opportunities in biomedical research to four undergraduate students, who participated in submitting research papers and conference proceedings. Two female high school students participated in the research activites and the activities were enrolled in two science competitions for high school students.

Overall, this study proposed a novel paradigm that mechanical damage alters the pericellular niche and transduces cells for damage repair. Also, repetitive calcium stimulus was suggested as novel clinical method for bone healing. Such findings will help to improve the current medical interventions for bone quality and health, and therefore reduce the bone fracture incidence.
